Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Renewables: Selling Demand Flexibility in The Future Electricity Grid

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The future electricity grid will have significant renewable generation. This generation is variable it is intermittent, unpredictable, and uncontrollable. Using conventional generation to back-up this variability defeats the emissions benefits of renewables and is very expensive. So the future grid must turn to demand flexibility which will play a critical role to mitigate renewable variability. Consumers will be transformed from passive recipients of power to active participants in providing services to balance supply and demand. This project seeks to explore business cases, market mechanisms, and pricing for various balancing services that demand flexibility can provide. These services include balancing supply and demand as the retail distribution level, and reducing congestion on lines at the wholesale transmission level. The broad agenda of this work is to support the deep penetration of renewable generation by developing and understanding the underlying economic research issues.

The future will have geographic clusters of distributed loads, generation, and storage. A load serving entity (LSE) represents the cluster in transactions with the grid. The LSE buys bulk power from the transmission grid in one hour blocks. At finer time scales, most of the power balance can be arranged internally by modulating storage and flexible loads within the cluster. This reduces the reliance on expensive and dirty reserve generation.
We explore appropriate market instruments such as options and forward contracts that support harnessing demand flexibility for balancing. These instruments allow for the lead-time to organize flexible loads, and account for the randomness in their availability.
We will study equilibria and price discovery for these instruments under various market models. Excess flexibility or storage capacity from a cluster can also be sold to other clusters. Bilateral arrangements between clusters can be clumsy. A better alternative is for clusters to submit their available flexibility to the system operator (SO). The SO conducts multi-period economic dispatch to minimize the social (fuel) cost. It determines optimal generation schedules and demand flexibility set points. Our value proposition here is that storage and flexibility can reduce congestion in transmission networks.
We will quantify the system benefit of demand flexibility in this context, and explore incentive schemes necessary for load participation, as well as the degree of coordination and control across buses necessary to realize these benefits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The electricity grid is evolving rapidly, driven by economic, security, and environmental concerns. What will Grid2050 look like? A large fraction, perhaps 50% or more, of the total energy will be supplied by renewable generation. Much of this generation will be small scale and distributed.  It is widely accepted that distribution side flexible demand and strategic storage must play key roles in any evolution of the electricity grid. This proposal is centered on investigating the economics of flexible demand and strategic storage resources and the specific roles they can play in Grid2050.

This project had 4 outcomes:

1. On the distribution side, we have developed a framework to analyze forward options as a natural instrument to sell demand response products. The options offer the issuer the lead time necessary to organize their demand response capabilities, and offer the holder the opportunity to hedge against quantity risk associated with intermittent renewable generation. Our analysis shows that options approximate the Arrow-Debreu gold standard of a spot market with modest loss of efficiency. 

2. On the transmission side, we have devised a novel multi-period economic dispatch approach that enables utilities to share storage and/or recruited demand flexibility. The systemic benefits stem from reduction in congestion costs which are sizeable (1B$ for 2014 in the PJM jurisdiction alone). We have shown how MPED reduced congestion, and schedules both storage/demand response and generation to maximize the social welfare. Adding constraints on utility revenue for their offered storage results in a difficult nonconvex problem. We have argued that bi-level optimization offers a good solution for these computationally challenging problems. Simulation studies support the promise of our approach.

3. Demand Response (DR) programs serve to reduce the demand for electricity at times when the supply is scarce and expensive. Consumers or agents with flexible consumption profiles are recruited by an aggregator who manages the DR program. The utility informs the aggregator of an anticipated DR event. In response, the aggregator is required to deliver a target reduction in electricity consumption of D KWh during the event to the utility. The aggregator calls on its pool of recruited agents to reduce their electricity use. Agents are paid for reducing their energy consumption from contractually established baselines. Baselines are counter-factual consumption estimates of the energy an agent would have consumed. This creates an incentive for agents to inflate their baselines in order to increase the payments they receive. There are several newsworthy cases of agents gaming their baseline for economic benefit. We have devised a novel self-reported baseline mechanism (SRBM) where agents self-report forecasts of their future consumption and their marginal utilities to an aggregator who manages the DR program. Under SRBM, we show that truthful reporting of baseline consumption and marginal utility is a dominant strategy for each agent. We show that agents are faithful to their baseline (or forecast) consumption when not called for DR, and that agents maximally reduce their consumption when called for DR.  We show that SRBM reduces the average cost to the aggregator of DR provision per KWh.

4.  Multi-lateral energy transactions. In future energy systems, millions of consumers will be able to offer electricity services. Commercial consumers may be willing to modulate their energy consumptions, residential consumers may wish to sell excess Photovoltaic (PV) generation, independent storage owners may wish to offer their storage capacity for sale. These new players participate alongside conventional generators and traditional loads to produce and consume electricity. Managing millions of micro-enery transactions is extremely challenging. These transactions have a diversity of constraints: generators may require a minimum production, demand response providers might require lead times, PV producers are uncertain about their output. In addition, there are system-level constraints such as limits on transmission lines. Traditionally, the system operator (SO) receives supply bids from generators and demand requests from utilities. It then schedules the least expensive generation assets to meet the demand through economic dispatch subject to transmission constraints. It determines nodeal prices for all market participants. This framework cannot balance supply and demand under the diversity of transactions and constraints that new particiapnts can offfer. We need a new paradigm for multi-lateral, multi-period, constrained energy transactions. We propose a novel platform called APEX (Automated Power EXchange) to support multi-lateral energy transactions.  The key idea is to define an atomic list of permissable transactions. Each transaction has the minimal fields: set of intervals for power delivey, end time, expiration, price, logical (and/or) constraints. Buyers and sellers can compose these atomic transactions to produce complex instrumnets that meet their constraints. An order book is populated with bids of transactions from buyers and sellers. The SO simply clears these using a number of possible algorithms: maximal matching, first come-first serve etc. We show that this approach relieves the SO of economic responsibility to focus exclusively on reliablity.
